001package net.tvburger.jdl.model.training;
002
003import net.tvburger.jdl.common.patterns.DomainObject;
004import net.tvburger.jdl.common.patterns.Strategy;
005import net.tvburger.jdl.common.utils.Pair;
006import net.tvburger.jdl.model.training.loss.BatchLossFunction;
007import net.tvburger.jdl.model.training.loss.DimensionLossFunction;
008import net.tvburger.jdl.model.training.loss.LossFunction;
009import net.tvburger.jdl.model.training.loss.SampleLossFunction;
010import net.tvburger.jdl.model.training.regularization.ExplicitRegularization;
011
012import java.util.Arrays;
013import java.util.List;
014import java.util.Set;
015
016/**
017 * Represents an objective function that extends the concept of a
018 * {@link LossFunction} to provide both loss aggregation and gradient
019 * computation.
020 *
021 * <p>
022 * An {@code ObjectiveFunction} defines how the overall loss is calculated
023 * across a batch of samples, as well as how the parameterGradients are determined
024 * for optimization algorithms (e.g., stochastic gradient descent).
025 * </p>
026 *
027 * <p>
028 * Unlike {@link DimensionLossFunction}, {@link SampleLossFunction}, or
029 * {@link BatchLossFunction}, which focus on specific granularities,
030 * an objective function typically provides the entry point for a training
031 * process, combining loss evaluation and gradient calculation in one place.
032 * </p>
033 */
034@DomainObject
035@Strategy(Strategy.Role.INTERFACE)
036public interface ObjectiveFunction<N extends Number> extends LossFunction<N> {
037
038    /**
039     * Calculates the loss for a batch of samples.
040     *
041     * <p>
042     * Each sample in the batch is represented as a {@link Pair} of
043     * {@code float[]} arrays, where the left element is the estimated
044     * (predicted) values and the right element is the target
045     * (expected) values. Implementations should define how individual
046     * sample losses are aggregated into a single scalar loss for the batch.
047     * </p>
048     *
049     * @param batch a list of samples, where each sample is a pair of
050     *              {@code float[]} arrays (estimated vs target)
051     * @return the aggregated loss value for the batch
052     */
053    N calculateLossWithoutRegularizationPenalty(List<Pair<N[], N[]>> batch);
054
055    default N calculateLoss(List<Pair<N[], N[]>> batch, N[] parameters) {
056        return getCurrentNumberType().add(calculateLossWithoutRegularizationPenalty(batch), calculateRegularizationPenalty(parameters));
057    }
058
059    N calculateRegularizationPenalty(N[] parameters);
060
061    /**
062     * Determines the parameterGradients of the objective function with respect to
063     * the estimated values, for a single sample.
064     *
065     * <p>
066     * Implementations should return a gradient array that corresponds in
067     * length and order to the {@code estimated} array, such that each entry
068     * can be used to update model parameters during optimization.
069     * </p>
070     *
071     * @param samples   the total number of samples in the batch
072     * @param estimated the predicted values for a sample
073     * @param target    the expected target values for the sample
074     * @return an array of parameterGradients, one per dimension of the input
075     */
076    N[] calculateGradient_dJ_da(int samples, N[] estimated, N[] target);
077
078    N regularizedGradient(N parameter);
079
080    boolean isOptimization();
081
082    default boolean isMinimization() {
083        return !isOptimization();
084    }
085
086    /**
087     * Creates an {@link ObjectiveFunction} that minimizes the loss
088     * according to the given loss function components.
089     *
090     * <p>
091     * This factory method composes together a {@link BatchLossFunction},
092     * a {@link SampleLossFunction}, and one or more
093     * {@link DimensionLossFunction}s into a concrete
094     * {@link ObjectiveFunction} implementation. The resulting objective
095     * function calculates dimension-level errors, aggregates them into
096     * sample losses, and then aggregates those sample losses into a
097     * batch-level loss suitable for optimization.
098     * </p>
099     *
100     * <p>
101     * The intent of this method is to provide a convenient entry point
102     * for constructing custom objective functions when the optimization
103     * goal is loss minimization (as is typical in regression and
104     * classification problems).
105     * </p>
106     *
107     * @param batchLossFunction      the function used to aggregate losses
108     *                               across the entire batch
109     * @param sampleLossFunction     the function used to aggregate losses
110     *                               within a single sample
111     * @param dimensionLossFunctions one or more functions used to compute
112     *                               loss at the individual dimension level
113     * @return a composed {@link ObjectiveFunction} that minimizes loss
114     */
115    @SafeVarargs
116    static <N extends Number> ObjectiveFunction<N> minimize(BatchLossFunction<N> batchLossFunction, SampleLossFunction<N> sampleLossFunction, DimensionLossFunction<N>... dimensionLossFunctions) {
117        return new ObjectiveFunctionImpl<>(batchLossFunction, sampleLossFunction, Arrays.asList(dimensionLossFunctions), false);
118    }
119
120    void addRegularization(ExplicitRegularization<N> regularization);
121
122    void removeRegularization(ExplicitRegularization<N> regularization);
123
124    Set<ExplicitRegularization<N>> getRegularizations();
125
126}
127
